On 8/4/05, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
> At 14:31 04/08/2005=
, you wrote:
>
> But for TTT?  You don't need to know anything about the op=
ponent.  

Well no, that's not true, as you seemed to point out in the prev=
ious
part of this post.

If you're goal is to win, whether you're playing a=
 single game or an
iterated series of games, it is *always* useful to have =
knowledge of
your opponent and their strengths and/or weaknesses.

If you'r=
e playing against a hand-coded player that, for example, is
always suscepti=
ble to a particular kind of forking maneuver, one which
you would never try=
 against an optimal opponent, that information is
very useful.

If you know=
 that your opponent is an optimal player, then you should
simply play for a=
 tie.  If you know your opponent is suboptimal, it is
always beneficial to =
know that they are suboptimal, and even moreso to
know their particular wea=
knesses so that you can exploit them.

Derek
